metadata.sermon_start_end: Jesus tells his disciples, in our Gospel reading, that they must have a “righteousness” that surpasses any punctilious moralism. And then Jesus intensifies the commandments of Sinai in the Sermon on the Mount to trace the way his followers are to give themselves over to the command of God [...] That is why we eat and drink here, a meal for the truly human toward which we grow.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's requirement of focusing on ONE specific passage. It treats Isaiah 58, Psalm 112, and Matthew 5 as a thematic cluster about 'true humanity.' By synthesizing these texts into a general concept of 'righteousness,' the preacher loses the specific 'NOWHERE else' quality of the individual pericopes.
quotes: If we take the sketches of the Psalm and the poem in Isaiah, we have a completely different notion of what it means to be “righteous.”
We have two sketches in our reading of that “truly human” that are worth pondering.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either Isaiah 58 or Psalm 112 as the sole foundation. Avoid using one text merely to illustrate a concept found in another.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a brief attempt to situate Isaiah 58 in a post-exilic 'worship war' context, but it is quickly modernized. The exegesis remains on the surface of the English translation without demonstrating the 'Hebrew and Greek' depth Dekker demands.
quotes: The poetry comes from a time when the Jews are having a big argument about what constitutes authentic worship.
The Pharisees, his opponents, had a careful notion of being righteous...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the historical-critical analysis of the specific Hebrew metaphors in Isaiah 58 (e.g., the 'yoke' or 'fasting') before jumping to modern analogies.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding social issues (minimum wage, debt, housing) and the 'zeitgeist' (Orange Alert anxiety, adult bookstores). However, it risks becoming a general ethical lecture on 'being a good neighbor' rather than a specific application of the text's unique revelation.
quotes: They do not participate in the Orange Alert anxiety of the fearful society around them
The poet is talking about oppressive, exploitative social and economic practices, for already in verse 3 there is mention of “oppressing workers,” surely with a bad minimum wage.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond 'social responsibility' as a general truth and ground the application in the specific 'present of revelation' offered by the text.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon avoids the 'block' structure (first all exegesis, then all application). It moves back and forth between the biblical 'sketches' and the modern 'adult,' which creates a sense of current relevance.
quotes: Sound familiar? It turns out, in this poem, that neither advocates for the traditional or the contemporary carry the day.
Now I am sensitive to the fact that I do not know any of you and my mandate is not to provoke.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'exposition' part is not just a summary but a deep dive that forces the application to be more than moral exhortation.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is heavily weighted toward 'gratitude' (ethics/action) and 'misery' (social injustice/narcissism). However, it is dangerously 'human-oriented' in a way Dekker warns against. Redemption is presented as 'growing into adulthood' rather than a vertical act of God.
quotes: The adulthood of the gospel toward which we grow is to become truly human
Get yourself together and live one thing in this world as a child of God.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Re-center the 'redemption' part on Christ’s work for us, rather than our work for the neighborhood. The sermon feels too much like 'man as the subject.'

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The preacher explicitly mentions the 'wicked' and the 'two sketches,' acknowledging the possibility of a life that 'comes to nothing.' This addresses Dekker's 'lostness in time,' though it avoids 'eternal loss.'
quotes: The “wicked” [the opposite of the righteous] see it and are angry... the desire of the wicked comes to nothing.
The self-preoccupied can never be satisfied.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Sharpen the 'temporal loss'—what does it mean for a community or soul to be truly 'lost' if it rejects this righteousness, beyond just being 'unsatisfied'?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as a teacher and an example of 'the truly human,' but He is not the 'telos' in the sense of the One who accomplishes what we cannot. The sermon leans toward Pelagianism: we must 'be like that' rather than 'living from grace.'
quotes: Be more like the God of mercy and generosity and forgiveness and abundance. Be like that!
The adulthood of the gospel toward which we grow is to become truly human...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Present Christ not just as the 'model adult' but as the Savior whose righteousness is imputed to the 'unrighteous' mentioned in the text.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1150 words, the sermon would take about 11-12 minutes to deliver. This is significantly below Dekker’s 20-minute minimum. The lack of 'breadth' results in a lack of 'depth,' as the preacher jumps between four different Bible books.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the duration to at least 20 minutes by dwelling longer on the specificities of one text rather than skimming the surface of many.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon fails the primary formal criterion by not focusing on a specific Bible passage, instead opting for a thematic synthesis of multiple texts. It lacks the required length (approx. 12 minutes) for substantive depth. While it is concrete in its social application and addresses the 'two ways' through the contrast of the righteous and the wicked, it is overly human-centric. It presents the Gospel as a call to 'authentic adulthood' and 'social responsibility' rather than a proclamation of the Word of God that shatters and restores the hearer through grace.
strengths: Concrete contemporary application regarding social justice and the 'zeitgeist' of anxiety.
Clear attempt to distinguish between the 'righteous' and 'wicked' (two ways).
Interwoven structure that avoids a dry, academic separation of text and life.
weaknesses: Thematic approach violates the 'one specific passage' rule.
Insufficient length (12 min) prevents the 'breadth' required for theological depth.
Moralistic tone: Christ is an example to follow rather than the Savior to be received.
Psychology and ethics are 'awake' and in the foreground, rather than 'sleeping' in the background.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a 'speech about the gospel' or 'the truly human' rather than an exposition and application of a specific Bible passage. It functions more as an ethical exhortation than a form of the Word of God.
